##

CVE-2024-20399
(6.0 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.31%

updated 2024-07-10T21:31:40

5 posts

A vulnerability in the CLI of Cisco NX-OS Software could allow an authenticated, local attacker to execute arbitrary commands as root on the underlying operating system of an affected device. This vulnerability is due to insufficient validation of arguments that are passed to specific configuration CLI commands. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by including crafted input as the argum

1 repos

https://github.com/Blootus/CVE-2024-20399-Cisco-RCE

breachhq at 2024-08-27T01:40:30.598Z ##

🚨#DataBreach🚨
On July 1, 2024, Cisco released an advisory about a command injection vulnerability in its NX-OS software, identified as CVE-2024-20399. This vulnerability, used by a threat group known as Velvet Ant, allows authenticated users with administrator credentials to execute arbitrary commands at the root level on affected Nexus switches. Sygnia Security discovered and reported this exploit, detailing how Velvet Ant compromised...
https://breach-hq.com/breaches/cisco/2024-aug

##
jbhall56 at 2024-08-23T11:54:15.743Z ##

The activity was observed early this year and involved the weaponization of CVE-2024-20399 (CVSS score: 6.0) to deliver bespoke malware and gain extensive control over the compromised system, facilitating both data exfiltration and persistent access. https://thehackernews.com/2024/08/chinese-hackers-exploit-zero-day-cisco.html

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-22T16:29:53.680Z ##

Sygnia: China-Nexus Threat Group ‘Velvet Ant’ Leverages a Zero-Day to Deploy Malware on Cisco Nexus Switches
See parent toot above for original Sygnia blog about the Chinese APT Velvet Ant exploiting CVE-2024-20399) as a zero-day. This blog post (I promise it's different) "highlights the technique used by Velvet Ant to compromise Cisco Switch appliances and use them to perform stealthy attacks." Sygnia describes post-exploitation activity and provides an analysis of the VELVETSHELL malware: "it was determined that it is a hybrid customized version of two open-source tools: TinyShell, a Unix backdoor, and 3proxy, a proxy tool...they were identified as being incorporated into a single binary." The only new IOC are file paths.

#threatintel #CVE_2024_20399 #China #cyberespionage #eitw #zeroday #vulnerability #activeexploitation #cisco #linux #nx #VelvetAnt #VelvetShell

##

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-22T16:29:53.000Z ##

Sygnia: China-Nexus Threat Group ‘Velvet Ant’ Leverages a Zero-Day to Deploy Malware on Cisco Nexus Switches
See parent toot above for original Sygnia blog about the Chinese APT Velvet Ant exploiting CVE-2024-20399) as a zero-day. This blog post (I promise it's different) "highlights the technique used by Velvet Ant to compromise Cisco Switch appliances and use them to perform stealthy attacks." Sygnia describes post-exploitation activity and provides an analysis of the VELVETSHELL malware: "it was determined that it is a hybrid customized version of two open-source tools: TinyShell, a Unix backdoor, and 3proxy, a proxy tool...they were identified as being incorporated into a single binary." The only new IOC are file paths.

CVE-2024-4068
(7.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-07-05T21:25:08

2 posts

The NPM package `braces` fails to limit the number of characters it can handle, which could lead to Memory Exhaustion. In `lib/parse.js,` if a malicious user sends "imbalanced braces" as input, the parsing will enter a loop, which will cause the program to start allocating heap memory without freeing it at any moment of the loop. Eventually, the JavaScript heap limit is reached, and the program wi

CVE-2019-1003029
(10.0 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.77%

updated 2024-07-05T17:55:08

1 posts

A sandbox bypass vulnerability exists in Jenkins Script Security Plugin 1.53 and earlier in src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/scriptsecurity/sandbox/groovy/GroovySandbox.java, src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/scriptsecurity/sandbox/groovy/SecureGroovyScript.java that allows attackers with Overall/Read permission to execute arbitrary code on the Jenkins master JVM.

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-20T15:39:20.000Z ##

Just FYI, CISA quietly updated a column for CVE-2024-23897 in the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog:

Known To Be Used in Ransomware Campaigns? Known

See parent toots above for information on the Jenkins Command Line Interface (CLI) Path Traversal Vulnerability.

Why you should care about CVE-2024-23897:

  • CISA confirmed that CVE-2024-23897 is a Known Exploited Vulnerability today and added it to the KEV Catalog.
  • It's had a Proof of Concept since at least 4 days after the security advisory.
  • Jenkins is an attractive target for threat actors. Four other Jenkins vulnerabilities are in CISA's KEV Catalog: CVE-2015-5317, CVE-2019-1003029, CVE-2019-1003030 and CVE-2018-1000861.
  • It's already had exploitation attempts since 25 January 2024
  • Trend Micro also noted active exploitation on 19 March 2024. See Recent attacks section.
  • CloudSEK noted on 25 July 2024 that threat actor IntelBroker exploited CVE-2024-23897 to breach BORN Group's systems, exfiltrating sensitive data from multiple clients.
  • Ransomware groups have been known to exploit it: Juniper said on 13 August 2024 that RansomEXX leveraged CVE-2024-23897 to gain initial unauthorized access to Brontoo Technology Solutions.

#CVE_2024_23897 #vulnerability #cve #Jenkins #kev #eitw #activeexploitation #ransomware

##

CVE-2024-3661
(7.6 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.05%

updated 2024-07-01T15:15:17.187000

1 posts

DHCP can add routes to a client’s routing table via the classless static route option (121). VPN-based security solutions that rely on routes to redirect traffic can be forced to leak traffic over the physical interface. An attacker on the same local network can read, disrupt, or possibly modify network traffic that was expected to be protected by the VPN.

mmablock at 2024-08-23T13:04:33.675Z ##

🛡️ People want to be able to use untrusted networks safely, this is the main benefit VPNs advertise themselves to have.

❗ Let's be honest, in some countries, even cell networks are not safe as operators work with Government to crackdown civil societies and really cant be treated as “trusted networks”.

Same thing goes to all networks that the user has no full control over, even friends home or workplace, not saying they are malicious, but the routers might not be “properly configured”, sometimes even the router admin credential were remain default and might be compromised (happened to my friend once), or the ISP / router manufecturer can simply push bad updates to your router and “MISCONFIGURE” your network.

For now, we could just consider all DHCP options to be a gigantic vulnerability, outside of simply providing IP addresses. Why would you want anyone to be able to remotely configure any of these things on your device in any context?

Networks where you’re not in control of the network (and I will add, where someone you trust is not in control of the network) are untrusted – no one who seriously cares about privacy and security would be using an ISP router, that’s extremely silly because at best you’ll get barely any updates and at worst, actively malicious updates.

https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-3661

https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2024/05/wider-view-tunnelvision-and-vpn-advice

_
#realmmablock #VPN #security #privacy #tunnelvision #vulnerability #ISP

Fortinet: Ransomware Roundup - Underground
Fortinet provides a threat actor spotlight on Underground Ransomware, concentrating on their attack chain. Initial infection is the exploitation of CVE-2023-36884 (7.5 high, disclosed 11 July 2023 by Microsoft, added to CISA's KEV Catalog 17 July 2024) Windows Search Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. The group may also use other common infection vectors such as email and purchasing access from an Initial Access Broker (IAB). Fortinet describes the ransom note, victimology and data leak site. IOC are provided.

screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T18:16:44.206Z ##

Akamai: Beware the Unpatchable: Corona Mirai Botnet Spreads via Zero-Day
Reference: CVE-2024-7029 (CNA: 8.7 high, disclosed 02 August 2024 by CISA) AVTECH IP camera command injection vulnerability. See parent toot above for initial reporting from Security Week.

Akamai finally provides a writeup explaining the situation: a Corona Mirai variant Botnet is leveraging a previously undisclosed zero-day vulnerability now tracked as CVE-2024-7029 to add vulnerable AVTECH IP camera devices to its collection. IOC are provided. They describe the vulnerability (quoted text verbatim, bold emphasis is Akamai's):

The first active campaign we observed began on March 18, 2024, but analysis showed activity for this variant as early as December 2023. The proof of concept (PoC) for CVE-2024-7029 has been publicly available since at least 2019, but it never had a proper CVE assignment until August 2024.

The exploit of this vulnerability allows an attacker to execute remote code on a target system. Here are some bonus CVEs being exploited in the wild for your consideration (to the KEV Catalog):

The botnet also targeted several other vulnerabilities including a Hadoop YARN RCE, CVE-2014-8361, and CVE-2017-17215.

#threatintel #mirai #botnet #vulnerability #zeroday #cve #CVE_2024_7029 #avtech #cisa #rce #poc #corona #hadoop

dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev at 2024-08-29T16:16:40.000Z ##

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General; The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare;

We return to the semi-regular AI-foucused Drop with a quick look at how to (quickly and easily!) make a custom Ollama model to make a small, useful tool.

Programming note: due to driving #4 to college Friday, there may not be a Drop. But, if the round trip is not too taxing, I’ll likley get one out int he late afternoon.

Type your email…

Subscribe

TL;DR

(This is an AI-generated summary of today’s Drop using Sonnet via Perplexity.)

  • A guide on creating a custom Ollama model using a Modelfile to generate concise names for CVE vulnerabilities, similar to CISA’s KEV catalog entries (https://github.com/ollama/ollama/blob/main/docs/modelfile.md)
  • Discussion of Google’s new Pixel 9 “Reimagine” feature, which allows users to manipulate photos using AI, raising concerns about the potential misuse of such technology (https://www.theverge.com/2024/8/21/24224084/google-pixel-9-reimagine-ai-photos)
  • Introduction to “The Inference,” a new editorial project by Danny Palmer published by Darktrace, exploring the impact of AI on cybersecurity and society (https://darktrace.com/the-inference)

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by Pixabay on Pexels.com

Longtime readers know I’m #notAFan of the “Open AI tax”. TL;DR for new readers is that I believe it is yugely important to ensure everyone had access to LLM/GPT tooling. These tools/services are not going away anytime soon; and, not knowing how to work with them puts other folks at an needless advantage. Ollama does a great job helping to level the playing field.

Ollama supports adding layers on top of existing models via something called a Modelfile. It’s a plain text file that lets you add in some parameters, prompts, examples, etc. so you don’t have to shunt them along with each new incantation. The format for these is, essentially:

# commentINSTRUCTION arguments

Some key instructions include:

  • FROM: Identifies the base model (mandatory)
  • PARAMETER: Customizes model behavior through various settings
  • TEMPLATE: Defines the prompt template sent to the model
  • SYSTEM: Sets up system messages
  • ADAPTER: Integrates adapters for QLoRA
  • LICENSE: Specifies legal licenses
  • MESSAGE: Adds preset message histories

You can inspect the configuration of models you download and use pretty simply:

$ ollama show phi:latest --modelfile# Modelfile generated by "ollama show"# To build a new Modelfile based on this, replace FROM with:# FROM phi:latestFROM /path/to/.ollama/models/blobs/sha256-04778965089b91318ad61d0995b7e44fad4b9a9f4e049d7be90932bf8812e828TEMPLATE "{{ if .System }}System: {{ .System }}{{ end }}User: {{ .Prompt }}Assistant:"SYSTEM A chat between a curious user and an artificial intelligence assistant. The assistant gives helpful answers to the user's questions.PARAMETER stop User:PARAMETER stop Assistant:PARAMETER stop System:LICENSE """MIT License … """

(They work in a similar fashion to Dockerfiles.)

You can go here for a more in-depth explanation of the instructions and values. I’m just going to briefly show how to make one to solve a fun “problem”.

I talk quite a bit about CISA’s Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog (KEV), and one nice thing the Keepers of KEV do for us is create a short name for any vulnerability they add to the catalog. CVE entries only have a longer-length description associated with their identifier, like CVE-2024-38856’s Apache OFBiz contains an incorrect authorization vulnerability that could allow remote code execution via a Groovy payload in the context of the OFBiz user process by an unauthenticated attacker.. The KEV entry for that uses the concise name of Apache OFBiz Incorrect Authorization Vulnerability, making it much easier to reference (and has way more info than just a bare CVE identifier).

At $WORK, we got it into our noggins to be as kind as the KEV Keepers and associate a concise name with any CVEs we display (and for an upcoming product/API feature). There is no way we were going to lovingly hand-craft those for a few hundred thousand entries. And, I’m loathe to give any AI vendor money. So, we built a custom PHI model to do this for us! And, are sharing it with y’all right here (we’ll working on posting the CVE ids with concise to GitHub when we’re done cleaning them up).

After a few iterations, here’s the Modelfile we ended up with:

FROM phi:latestPARAMETER temperature 0.0PARAMETER stop "\n"PARAMETER num_predict 30PARAMETER top_p 0.95SYSTEM """You are an AI system specializing in generating concise short names for vulnerabilities described by CVEs. Your task is to convert verbose CVE descriptions into clear, descriptive titles that resemble entries in CISA's Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Stop generating output immediately after providing the short name.PROMPT Given a CVE description, create a short name similar to those used in CISA's KEV catalog. The short name should be concise, descriptive, and highlight the affected product or vulnerability type. Do not provide additional information or explanations. The response should be under 10 words and should end immediately after the short name.Examples:CVE description: A vulnerability in the TCP/IP stack of Cisco IOS XR Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.Short name: Cisco IOS XR TCP/IP Stack DoS VulnerabilityCVE description: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, CVE-2021-27065.Short name: Microsoft Exchange Server RCE VulnerabilityNow, create a short name for this CVE:"""

The temperature controls the “creativity” of the output, with 0.0 being fully deterministic. Even with that, we were getting some odd output behavior, so we added a “please stop generating” hint at when it outputs a newline, set the max number of output tokens to 30 (I may change that to 20), and asked it to only make high “next token” probability choices.

Rather than muck with special tokens, I went with a basic prompt-with-few-shot-examples approach.

To make our new model, we just:

$ ollama create cve-shortener -f ./Modelfile

Then just try it out:

$ ollama run cve-shortener 'Topline Opportunity Form (aka XLS Opp form) before 2015-02-15 does not properly restrict access to database-connection strings, which allows attackers to read the cleartext version of sensitive credential and e-mail address information via unspecified vectors.'Topline Opportunity Form (XLS Opp) Database Vulnerability

Like most LLM/GPT output in API contexts, you’ll need to add some guardrails for cleaning up results or retrying the prompt. (Yes, even with all the constraints in the Modelfile, this one still borks output every so often.)

On my aging Apple Silicon box, each call takes ~200-600ms, depending on the inputs and other system GPU load.

If you find yourself repeating prompts, this is a lightweight way to avoid doing so. And, if you have some similar, focused tasks that need doing, getting a hand from our AI overlords can help save quite a bit of time.

The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by cottonbro studio on Pexels.com

Super quick section, since I believe Welch’s examples say everything vs. have me blather much.

Chris Welch, an editor over at The Verge, acquired one of Google’s new Pixel 9 devices and gave the new Reimagine feature a go and posted some results on Threads and The Verge. This, to me, is a pretty terrifying new capability.

We’re already awash in deepfakes, photorealistic child image exploitation, advanced phishing, and shady political campaigns making it almost impossible to tell truth from fiction. The last thing we needed was to commodify this tech so anyone who can afford a certain class of portable glowing rectangles can get in on the gambit.

Let’s hope the majority of uses are benign/silly.

The Inference

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]

Another quick section, as this content also speaks for itself pretty well.

Danny Palmer is an excellent writer on cybersecurity topics. He has a new editorial project that’s being published by cybersecurity vendor Darktrace (yeah, that’s “a thing” in my line of work).

The Inference explores the impact of AI on the world around us, starting within the security operations center and expanding to business and society writ large. Features on it analyze data, trends, and perspectives from experts inside and outside of Darktrace to educate and inspire readers about the role that AI plays in enabling innovation and how it can be applied safely and securely.

I link to it since the first few pieces:

  • AI and the biggest election year ever – are we ready?
  • The role of IT support engineering in the age of AI
  • In conversation with Professor Mike Woolridge
  • Malware-as-a-Service: what you need to know about this persistent cyber threat

were very well crafted, and I thought more than a few readers would want to get this into their RSS feeds.

(As usual, I get nothing for Dropping a link to this post, save for providing y’all with something I found interesting.)

FIN

Remember, you can follow and interact with the full text of The Daily Drop’s free posts on Mastodon via @dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev ☮️

https://dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/2024/08/29/drop-523-2024-08-29-happy-thursdai/

CVE-2024-4577

updated 2024-06-21T21:35:02

In PHP versions 8.1.* before 8.1.29, 8.2.* before 8.2.20, 8.3.* before 8.3.8, when using Apache and PHP-CGI on Windows, if the system is set up to use certain code pages, Windows may use "Best-Fit" behavior to replace characters in command line given to Win32 API functions. PHP CGI module may misinterpret those characters as PHP options, which may allow a malicious user to pass options to PHP bina

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-20T14:08:22.000Z ##

Symantec: New Backdoor Targeting Taiwan Employs Stealthy Communications
Symantec describes a new backdoor (dubbed Msupedge) targeting a Taiwanese university. The most notable feature of this backdoor is that it communicates with a Command and Control (C2) server via DNS traffic. They provide a short technical analysis of Msupedge. Symantec suggests that the initial access vector was through CVE-2024-4577 (9.8 critical, disclosed 06 June 2024 by PHP, added to CISA KEV Catalog 12 June 2024) PHP-CGI OS Command Injection Vulnerability.) IOC provided.

See related The Hacker News reporting: Hackers Exploit PHP Vulnerability to Deploy Stealthy Msupedge Backdoor

#threatintel #msupedge #malwareanalysis #cyberespionage #IOC #CVE_2024_4577 #eitw #activeexploitation #vulnerability #PHP #CVE

CVE-2024-22259
(8.1 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.06%

updated 2024-06-10T18:31:58

2 posts

Applications that use UriComponentsBuilder in Spring Framework to parse an externally provided URL (e.g. through a query parameter) AND perform validation checks on the host of the parsed URL may be vulnerable to a open redirect https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/601.html  attack or to a SSRF attack if the URL is used after passing validation checks. This is the same as CVE-2024-22243 https

Atlassian security advisory: Security Bulletin - August 20 2024

  • Bamboo Data Center and Server:
    • CVE-2024-21689 (7.6 High) RCE
    • CVE-2024-29857 (7.5 high) DoS
  • Confluence Data Center and Server:
    • CVE-2024-34750 (7.5 high) DoS
    • CVE-2024-21690 (7.1 high) Reflected XSS and CSRF
  • Crowd Data Center and Server
    • CVE-2024-22259 (8.1 high) SSRF
    • CVE-2024-22243 (8.1 high) SSRF
    • CVE-2024-22262 (8.1 high) SSRF
  • Jira Data Center and Server:
    • CVE-2024-34750 (7.5 high) DoS
  • Jira Service Management Data Center and Server:
    • CVE-2024-34750 (7.5 high) DoS

CVE-2024-34750 is an Apache tomcat-coyote dependency vulnerability affecting multiple products, hence the duplicate entries. At a glance, no mention of exploitation.

#Atlassian #PatchTuesday #Vulnerability #CVE #bamboo #Confluence

##

CVE-2024-35178
(7.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-06-06T21:26:55

2 posts

### Summary Jupyter Server on Windows has a vulnerability that lets unauthenticated attackers leak the NTLMv2 password hash of the Windows user running the Jupyter server. An attacker can crack this password to gain access to the Windows machine hosting the Jupyter server, or access other network-accessible machines or 3rd party services using that credential. Or an attacker perform an NTLM relay

screaminggoat at 2024-08-23T13:56:45.074Z ##

Horizon3: NTLM Credential Theft in Python Windows Applications
NTLMv2 hash theft is possible on Windows hosts through the exploitation of Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF). Horizon3 covers SSRF vulnerabilities leading to NTLMv2 hash disclosure in three of the most popular Python frameworks out there: Gradio by Hugging Face, which powers several popular AI tools; Jupyter Server, which underpins Jupyter Notebook and JupyterLab; and Streamlit from Snowflake.

  • CVE-2024-34510 (NTLMv2 Hash Disclosure in Gradio)
  • CVE-2024-35178 (NTLMv2 Hash Disclosure in Jupyter Server)
  • CVE-2024-42474 (NTLMv2 Hash Disclosure in Streamlit)

The vulnerabilities disclosed here relate to how these Python frameworks retrieve files. Specifically, in Python, any file system operation performed on insufficiently validated input can lead to the leakage of NTLMv2 hashes, and can be exploited by unauthenticated attackers.

#Gradio #Streamlit #Jupyter #vulnerability #CVE_2024_34510 #CVE_2024_35178 #CVE_2024_42474 #cve

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-23T13:56:45.000Z ##

##

CVE-2023-48795
(5.9 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 96.53%

updated 2024-05-02T13:18:40

2 posts

### Summary Terrapin is a prefix truncation attack targeting the SSH protocol. More precisely, Terrapin breaks the integrity of SSH's secure channel. By carefully adjusting the sequence numbers during the handshake, an attacker can remove an arbitrary amount of messages sent by the client or server at the beginning of the secure channel without the client or server noticing it. ### Mitigations

1 repos

https://github.com/RUB-NDS/Terrapin-Artifacts

TomSellers at 2024-08-29T16:27:28.485Z ##

For folks with Synology NAS gear that is a bit older but still new enough to support DSM 7.x:

Synology has released DSM 7.2.2-72803 to fix a bunch of bugs and at least 6 CVEs. One of those CVEs is CVE-2023-48795 which is the Terrapin vuln.

For older gear this will NOT show up in the updates list and will need to be manually downloaded and installed.

Release notes: https://www.synology.com/en-us/releaseNote/DSM

The link above includes a list of models requiring manual install as well as a link to the Download center.

#Security #Patches #Synology

##
TomSellers@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-29T16:27:28.000Z ##

Tenable: AA24-241A : Joint Cybersecurity Advisory on Iran-based Cyber Actors Targeting US Organizations
Tenable provides an impressive analysis of CISA's joint cybersecurity advisory about Iranian actors targeting U.S. organizations with ransomware (see parent toots above). They list out the CVEs leveraged, including CVE-2024-3400, CVE-2024-24919, CVE-2019-19781, CVE-2023-3519, CVE-2022-1388, and CVE-2024-21887. (I hate how I recognize every CVE ID based on how often I write about VPN and edge networking device vulnerabilities.) Tenable has graphics of Shodan searches for internet-facing instances, MITRE ATT&CK TTPs, and Tenable plugins.

The issue was addressed with improved checks. This issue is fixed in Safari 16.6.1, macOS Ventura 13.6, OS 17.0.1 and iPadOS 17.0.1, iOS 16.7 and iPadOS 16.7. Processing web content may lead to arbitrary code execution. Apple is aware of a report that this issue may have been actively exploited against versions of iOS before iOS 16.7.

screaminggoat at 2024-08-29T13:31:26.914Z ##

Google Threat Analysis Group (TAG) State-backed attackers and commercial surveillance vendors repeatedly use the same exploits
Google TAG observed multiple in-the-wild exploit campaigns, between November 2023 and July 2024, delivered from a watering hole attack on Mongolian government websites. They assess with moderate confidence the campaigns are linked to the Russian government-backed actor APT29. In each iteration of the watering hole campaigns, the attackers used exploits that were identical or strikingly similar to exploits previously used by commercial surveillance vendors (CSVs) Intellexa and NSO Group. Google TAG provides a timeline of the watering hole attack, Apple Safari campaign, Google Chrome campaign, and the Exploit reuse timeline. IOC provided.

APT29, aka Midnight Blizzard and Cozy Bear, is publicly attributed to Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the U.S. Government.

See related Bleeping Computer reporting: Russian APT29 hackers use iOS, Chrome exploits created by spyware vendors

#googletag #apt29 #Russia #cyberespionage #threatintel #infosec #IOC #intellexa #nsogroup #CVE_2023_41993 #CVE_2024_5274 #CVE_2024_4671 #CVE_2023_41993 #CVE_2021_1879 #CVE_2021_37973

CVE-2024-31214
(9.6 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-04-10T19:49:51.183000

2 posts

Traccar is an open source GPS tracking system. Traccar versions 5.1 through 5.12 allow arbitrary files to be uploaded through the device image upload API. Attackers have full control over the file contents, full control over the directory where the file is stored, full control over the file extension, and partial control over the file name. While it's not for an attacker to overwrite an existing

screaminggoat at 2024-08-23T13:45:19.797Z ##

Horizon3: Traccar 5 Remote Code Execution Vulnerabilities
Traccar is a popular open source GPS tracking system used both by people for personal use and businesses for fleet management. Horizon3 covers two related path traversal (cc: @reverseics @cR0w) vulnerabilities affecting Traccar 5 that could lead to RCE. This is a walkthrough of CVE-2024-31214 and CVE-2024-24809.

Beyond addressing the specific issues, the biggest improvement we facilitated was turning self-registration off by default starting in Traccar 6. This significantly reduces the attack surface available to unauthenticated attackers and will have a lasting impact on improving the security posture of Traccar for years to come.

#Traccar #vulnerability #CVE #CVE_2024_31214 #CVE_2024_24809

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-23T13:45:19.000Z ##

Horizon3: Traccar 5 Remote Code Execution Vulnerabilities
Traccar is a popular open source GPS tracking system used both by people for personal use and businesses for fleet management. Horizon3 covers two related path traversal (cc: @reverseics @cR0w) vulnerabilities affecting Traccar 5 that could lead to RCE. This is a walkthrough of CVE-2024-31214 and CVE-2024-24809.

Beyond addressing the specific issues, the biggest improvement we facilitated was turning self-registration off by default starting in Traccar 6. This significantly reduces the attack surface available to unauthenticated attackers and will have a lasting impact on improving the security posture of Traccar for years to come.

#Traccar #vulnerability #CVE #CVE_2024_31214 #CVE_2024_24809

##

CVE-2024-24809
(8.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.05%

updated 2024-04-10T19:49:51.183000

2 posts

Traccar is an open source GPS tracking system. Versions prior to 6.0 are vulnerable to path traversal and unrestricted upload of file with dangerous type. Since the system allows registration by default, attackers can acquire ordinary user permissions by registering an account and exploit this vulnerability to upload files with the prefix `device.` under any folder. Attackers can use this vulnerab

Nuclei template

screaminggoat at 2024-08-23T13:45:19.797Z ##

Horizon3: Traccar 5 Remote Code Execution Vulnerabilities
Traccar is a popular open source GPS tracking system used both by people for personal use and businesses for fleet management. Horizon3 covers two related path traversal (cc: @reverseics @cR0w) vulnerabilities affecting Traccar 5 that could lead to RCE. This is a walkthrough of CVE-2024-31214 and CVE-2024-24809.

Beyond addressing the specific issues, the biggest improvement we facilitated was turning self-registration off by default starting in Traccar 6. This significantly reduces the attack surface available to unauthenticated attackers and will have a lasting impact on improving the security posture of Traccar for years to come.

#Traccar #vulnerability #CVE #CVE_2024_31214 #CVE_2024_24809

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-23T13:45:19.000Z ##

Horizon3: Traccar 5 Remote Code Execution Vulnerabilities
Traccar is a popular open source GPS tracking system used both by people for personal use and businesses for fleet management. Horizon3 covers two related path traversal (cc: @reverseics @cR0w) vulnerabilities affecting Traccar 5 that could lead to RCE. This is a walkthrough of CVE-2024-31214 and CVE-2024-24809.

Beyond addressing the specific issues, the biggest improvement we facilitated was turning self-registration off by default starting in Traccar 6. This significantly reduces the attack surface available to unauthenticated attackers and will have a lasting impact on improving the security posture of Traccar for years to come.

#Traccar #vulnerability #CVE #CVE_2024_31214 #CVE_2024_24809

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-30T13:05:57.210Z ##

Trend Micro: Silent Intrusions: Godzilla Fileless Backdoors Targeting Atlassian Confluence
Reference: CVE-2023-22527 (CNA: 10.0/NVD: 9.8 critical, disclosed 16 January 2024 by Atlassian, added to CISA's KEV Catalog 24 January 2024) Atlassian Confluence Data Center and Server Template Injection Vulnerability (RCE)

Not even two days later, Trend Micro reports more CVE-2024-22527 exploitation. This time, a loader leads to an in-memory fileless backdoor known as the Godzilla webshell. The original malware author claims that Godzilla avoids detection by using Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) encryption for its network traffic and boasts a very low static detection rate across various security vendor products. Trend Micro describes the infection chain and shares IOC.

#threatintel #godzilla #backdoor #CVE_2023_22527 #Atlassian #Confluence #vulnerability #CVE #eitw #activeexploitation #IOC #infosec #cybersecurity

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T13:47:50.544Z ##

Trend Micro: Cryptojacking via CVE-2023-22527: Dissecting a Full-Scale Cryptomining Ecosystem
Reference: CVE-2023-22527 (CNA: 10.0/NVD: 9.8 critical, disclosed 16 January 2024 by Atlassian, added to CISA's KEV Catalog 24 January 2024) Atlassian Confluence Data Center and Server Template Injection Vulnerability (Remote Code Execution)
Trend Micro details how three main threat actors are exploiting CVE-2023-22527 for cryptomining operations. They also observed a high number of exploitations attempts since from mid-June to the end of July 2024. The resulting activities include deployment of shell scripts and XMRig miners, targeting of SSH endpoints, killing competing cryptomining processes (there's no honor among thieves after all), and maintaining persistence via cron jobs. Trend Micro provides hunting queries, indicators of compromise and mapped MITRE ATT&CK TTPs.

#threatintel #cryptojacking #cryptomining #CVE_2023_22527 #Atlassian #Confluence #eitw #vulnerability #IOC #xmrig #mitreattack

dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev at 2024-08-29T16:16:40.000Z ##

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General; The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare;

We return to the semi-regular AI-foucused Drop with a quick look at how to (quickly and easily!) make a custom Ollama model to make a small, useful tool.

Programming note: due to driving #4 to college Friday, there may not be a Drop. But, if the round trip is not too taxing, I’ll likley get one out int he late afternoon.

Type your email…

Subscribe

TL;DR

(This is an AI-generated summary of today’s Drop using Sonnet via Perplexity.)

  • A guide on creating a custom Ollama model using a Modelfile to generate concise names for CVE vulnerabilities, similar to CISA’s KEV catalog entries (https://github.com/ollama/ollama/blob/main/docs/modelfile.md)
  • Discussion of Google’s new Pixel 9 “Reimagine” feature, which allows users to manipulate photos using AI, raising concerns about the potential misuse of such technology (https://www.theverge.com/2024/8/21/24224084/google-pixel-9-reimagine-ai-photos)
  • Introduction to “The Inference,” a new editorial project by Danny Palmer published by Darktrace, exploring the impact of AI on cybersecurity and society (https://darktrace.com/the-inference)

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by Pixabay on Pexels.com

Longtime readers know I’m #notAFan of the “Open AI tax”. TL;DR for new readers is that I believe it is yugely important to ensure everyone had access to LLM/GPT tooling. These tools/services are not going away anytime soon; and, not knowing how to work with them puts other folks at an needless advantage. Ollama does a great job helping to level the playing field.

Ollama supports adding layers on top of existing models via something called a Modelfile. It’s a plain text file that lets you add in some parameters, prompts, examples, etc. so you don’t have to shunt them along with each new incantation. The format for these is, essentially:

# commentINSTRUCTION arguments

Some key instructions include:

  • FROM: Identifies the base model (mandatory)
  • PARAMETER: Customizes model behavior through various settings
  • TEMPLATE: Defines the prompt template sent to the model
  • SYSTEM: Sets up system messages
  • ADAPTER: Integrates adapters for QLoRA
  • LICENSE: Specifies legal licenses
  • MESSAGE: Adds preset message histories

You can inspect the configuration of models you download and use pretty simply:

$ ollama show phi:latest --modelfile# Modelfile generated by "ollama show"# To build a new Modelfile based on this, replace FROM with:# FROM phi:latestFROM /path/to/.ollama/models/blobs/sha256-04778965089b91318ad61d0995b7e44fad4b9a9f4e049d7be90932bf8812e828TEMPLATE "{{ if .System }}System: {{ .System }}{{ end }}User: {{ .Prompt }}Assistant:"SYSTEM A chat between a curious user and an artificial intelligence assistant. The assistant gives helpful answers to the user's questions.PARAMETER stop User:PARAMETER stop Assistant:PARAMETER stop System:LICENSE """MIT License … """

(They work in a similar fashion to Dockerfiles.)

You can go here for a more in-depth explanation of the instructions and values. I’m just going to briefly show how to make one to solve a fun “problem”.

I talk quite a bit about CISA’s Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog (KEV), and one nice thing the Keepers of KEV do for us is create a short name for any vulnerability they add to the catalog. CVE entries only have a longer-length description associated with their identifier, like CVE-2024-38856’s Apache OFBiz contains an incorrect authorization vulnerability that could allow remote code execution via a Groovy payload in the context of the OFBiz user process by an unauthenticated attacker.. The KEV entry for that uses the concise name of Apache OFBiz Incorrect Authorization Vulnerability, making it much easier to reference (and has way more info than just a bare CVE identifier).

At $WORK, we got it into our noggins to be as kind as the KEV Keepers and associate a concise name with any CVEs we display (and for an upcoming product/API feature). There is no way we were going to lovingly hand-craft those for a few hundred thousand entries. And, I’m loathe to give any AI vendor money. So, we built a custom PHI model to do this for us! And, are sharing it with y’all right here (we’ll working on posting the CVE ids with concise to GitHub when we’re done cleaning them up).

After a few iterations, here’s the Modelfile we ended up with:

FROM phi:latestPARAMETER temperature 0.0PARAMETER stop "\n"PARAMETER num_predict 30PARAMETER top_p 0.95SYSTEM """You are an AI system specializing in generating concise short names for vulnerabilities described by CVEs. Your task is to convert verbose CVE descriptions into clear, descriptive titles that resemble entries in CISA's Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Stop generating output immediately after providing the short name.PROMPT Given a CVE description, create a short name similar to those used in CISA's KEV catalog. The short name should be concise, descriptive, and highlight the affected product or vulnerability type. Do not provide additional information or explanations. The response should be under 10 words and should end immediately after the short name.Examples:CVE description: A vulnerability in the TCP/IP stack of Cisco IOS XR Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.Short name: Cisco IOS XR TCP/IP Stack DoS VulnerabilityCVE description: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, CVE-2021-27065.Short name: Microsoft Exchange Server RCE VulnerabilityNow, create a short name for this CVE:"""

The temperature controls the “creativity” of the output, with 0.0 being fully deterministic. Even with that, we were getting some odd output behavior, so we added a “please stop generating” hint at when it outputs a newline, set the max number of output tokens to 30 (I may change that to 20), and asked it to only make high “next token” probability choices.

Rather than muck with special tokens, I went with a basic prompt-with-few-shot-examples approach.

To make our new model, we just:

$ ollama create cve-shortener -f ./Modelfile

Then just try it out:

$ ollama run cve-shortener 'Topline Opportunity Form (aka XLS Opp form) before 2015-02-15 does not properly restrict access to database-connection strings, which allows attackers to read the cleartext version of sensitive credential and e-mail address information via unspecified vectors.'Topline Opportunity Form (XLS Opp) Database Vulnerability

Like most LLM/GPT output in API contexts, you’ll need to add some guardrails for cleaning up results or retrying the prompt. (Yes, even with all the constraints in the Modelfile, this one still borks output every so often.)

On my aging Apple Silicon box, each call takes ~200-600ms, depending on the inputs and other system GPU load.

If you find yourself repeating prompts, this is a lightweight way to avoid doing so. And, if you have some similar, focused tasks that need doing, getting a hand from our AI overlords can help save quite a bit of time.

The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by cottonbro studio on Pexels.com

Super quick section, since I believe Welch’s examples say everything vs. have me blather much.

Chris Welch, an editor over at The Verge, acquired one of Google’s new Pixel 9 devices and gave the new Reimagine feature a go and posted some results on Threads and The Verge. This, to me, is a pretty terrifying new capability.

We’re already awash in deepfakes, photorealistic child image exploitation, advanced phishing, and shady political campaigns making it almost impossible to tell truth from fiction. The last thing we needed was to commodify this tech so anyone who can afford a certain class of portable glowing rectangles can get in on the gambit.

Let’s hope the majority of uses are benign/silly.

The Inference

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]

Another quick section, as this content also speaks for itself pretty well.

Danny Palmer is an excellent writer on cybersecurity topics. He has a new editorial project that’s being published by cybersecurity vendor Darktrace (yeah, that’s “a thing” in my line of work).

The Inference explores the impact of AI on the world around us, starting within the security operations center and expanding to business and society writ large. Features on it analyze data, trends, and perspectives from experts inside and outside of Darktrace to educate and inspire readers about the role that AI plays in enabling innovation and how it can be applied safely and securely.

I link to it since the first few pieces:

  • AI and the biggest election year ever – are we ready?
  • The role of IT support engineering in the age of AI
  • In conversation with Professor Mike Woolridge
  • Malware-as-a-Service: what you need to know about this persistent cyber threat

were very well crafted, and I thought more than a few readers would want to get this into their RSS feeds.

(As usual, I get nothing for Dropping a link to this post, save for providing y’all with something I found interesting.)

#4

CVE-2021-26858
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 18.40%

updated 2024-01-07T05:05:09

1 posts

10 repos

https://github.com/SCS-Labs/HAFNIUM-Microsoft-Exchange-0day

https://github.com/sgnls/exchange-0days-202103

https://github.com/WiredPulse/Invoke-HAFNIUMCheck.ps1

https://github.com/34zY/APT-Backpack

https://github.com/cert-lv/exchange_webshell_detection

https://github.com/soteria-security/HAFNIUM-IOC

https://github.com/DCScoder/Exchange_IOC_Hunter

https://github.com/byinarie/Zirconium

dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev at 2024-08-29T16:16:40.000Z ##

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General; The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare;

We return to the semi-regular AI-foucused Drop with a quick look at how to (quickly and easily!) make a custom Ollama model to make a small, useful tool.

Programming note: due to driving #4 to college Friday, there may not be a Drop. But, if the round trip is not too taxing, I’ll likley get one out int he late afternoon.

Type your email…

Subscribe

TL;DR

(This is an AI-generated summary of today’s Drop using Sonnet via Perplexity.)

  • A guide on creating a custom Ollama model using a Modelfile to generate concise names for CVE vulnerabilities, similar to CISA’s KEV catalog entries (https://github.com/ollama/ollama/blob/main/docs/modelfile.md)
  • Discussion of Google’s new Pixel 9 “Reimagine” feature, which allows users to manipulate photos using AI, raising concerns about the potential misuse of such technology (https://www.theverge.com/2024/8/21/24224084/google-pixel-9-reimagine-ai-photos)
  • Introduction to “The Inference,” a new editorial project by Danny Palmer published by Darktrace, exploring the impact of AI on cybersecurity and society (https://darktrace.com/the-inference)

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by Pixabay on Pexels.com

Longtime readers know I’m #notAFan of the “Open AI tax”. TL;DR for new readers is that I believe it is yugely important to ensure everyone had access to LLM/GPT tooling. These tools/services are not going away anytime soon; and, not knowing how to work with them puts other folks at an needless advantage. Ollama does a great job helping to level the playing field.

Ollama supports adding layers on top of existing models via something called a Modelfile. It’s a plain text file that lets you add in some parameters, prompts, examples, etc. so you don’t have to shunt them along with each new incantation. The format for these is, essentially:

# commentINSTRUCTION arguments

Some key instructions include:

  • FROM: Identifies the base model (mandatory)
  • PARAMETER: Customizes model behavior through various settings
  • TEMPLATE: Defines the prompt template sent to the model
  • SYSTEM: Sets up system messages
  • ADAPTER: Integrates adapters for QLoRA
  • LICENSE: Specifies legal licenses
  • MESSAGE: Adds preset message histories

You can inspect the configuration of models you download and use pretty simply:

$ ollama show phi:latest --modelfile# Modelfile generated by "ollama show"# To build a new Modelfile based on this, replace FROM with:# FROM phi:latestFROM /path/to/.ollama/models/blobs/sha256-04778965089b91318ad61d0995b7e44fad4b9a9f4e049d7be90932bf8812e828TEMPLATE "{{ if .System }}System: {{ .System }}{{ end }}User: {{ .Prompt }}Assistant:"SYSTEM A chat between a curious user and an artificial intelligence assistant. The assistant gives helpful answers to the user's questions.PARAMETER stop User:PARAMETER stop Assistant:PARAMETER stop System:LICENSE """MIT License … """

(They work in a similar fashion to Dockerfiles.)

You can go here for a more in-depth explanation of the instructions and values. I’m just going to briefly show how to make one to solve a fun “problem”.

I talk quite a bit about CISA’s Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog (KEV), and one nice thing the Keepers of KEV do for us is create a short name for any vulnerability they add to the catalog. CVE entries only have a longer-length description associated with their identifier, like CVE-2024-38856’s Apache OFBiz contains an incorrect authorization vulnerability that could allow remote code execution via a Groovy payload in the context of the OFBiz user process by an unauthenticated attacker.. The KEV entry for that uses the concise name of Apache OFBiz Incorrect Authorization Vulnerability, making it much easier to reference (and has way more info than just a bare CVE identifier).

At $WORK, we got it into our noggins to be as kind as the KEV Keepers and associate a concise name with any CVEs we display (and for an upcoming product/API feature). There is no way we were going to lovingly hand-craft those for a few hundred thousand entries. And, I’m loathe to give any AI vendor money. So, we built a custom PHI model to do this for us! And, are sharing it with y’all right here (we’ll working on posting the CVE ids with concise to GitHub when we’re done cleaning them up).

After a few iterations, here’s the Modelfile we ended up with:

FROM phi:latestPARAMETER temperature 0.0PARAMETER stop "\n"PARAMETER num_predict 30PARAMETER top_p 0.95SYSTEM """You are an AI system specializing in generating concise short names for vulnerabilities described by CVEs. Your task is to convert verbose CVE descriptions into clear, descriptive titles that resemble entries in CISA's Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Stop generating output immediately after providing the short name.PROMPT Given a CVE description, create a short name similar to those used in CISA's KEV catalog. The short name should be concise, descriptive, and highlight the affected product or vulnerability type. Do not provide additional information or explanations. The response should be under 10 words and should end immediately after the short name.Examples:CVE description: A vulnerability in the TCP/IP stack of Cisco IOS XR Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.Short name: Cisco IOS XR TCP/IP Stack DoS VulnerabilityCVE description: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, CVE-2021-27065.Short name: Microsoft Exchange Server RCE VulnerabilityNow, create a short name for this CVE:"""

The temperature controls the “creativity” of the output, with 0.0 being fully deterministic. Even with that, we were getting some odd output behavior, so we added a “please stop generating” hint at when it outputs a newline, set the max number of output tokens to 30 (I may change that to 20), and asked it to only make high “next token” probability choices.

Rather than muck with special tokens, I went with a basic prompt-with-few-shot-examples approach.

To make our new model, we just:

$ ollama create cve-shortener -f ./Modelfile

Then just try it out:

$ ollama run cve-shortener 'Topline Opportunity Form (aka XLS Opp form) before 2015-02-15 does not properly restrict access to database-connection strings, which allows attackers to read the cleartext version of sensitive credential and e-mail address information via unspecified vectors.'Topline Opportunity Form (XLS Opp) Database Vulnerability

Like most LLM/GPT output in API contexts, you’ll need to add some guardrails for cleaning up results or retrying the prompt. (Yes, even with all the constraints in the Modelfile, this one still borks output every so often.)

On my aging Apple Silicon box, each call takes ~200-600ms, depending on the inputs and other system GPU load.

If you find yourself repeating prompts, this is a lightweight way to avoid doing so. And, if you have some similar, focused tasks that need doing, getting a hand from our AI overlords can help save quite a bit of time.

The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by cottonbro studio on Pexels.com

Super quick section, since I believe Welch’s examples say everything vs. have me blather much.

Chris Welch, an editor over at The Verge, acquired one of Google’s new Pixel 9 devices and gave the new Reimagine feature a go and posted some results on Threads and The Verge. This, to me, is a pretty terrifying new capability.

We’re already awash in deepfakes, photorealistic child image exploitation, advanced phishing, and shady political campaigns making it almost impossible to tell truth from fiction. The last thing we needed was to commodify this tech so anyone who can afford a certain class of portable glowing rectangles can get in on the gambit.

Let’s hope the majority of uses are benign/silly.

The Inference

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]

Another quick section, as this content also speaks for itself pretty well.

Danny Palmer is an excellent writer on cybersecurity topics. He has a new editorial project that’s being published by cybersecurity vendor Darktrace (yeah, that’s “a thing” in my line of work).

The Inference explores the impact of AI on the world around us, starting within the security operations center and expanding to business and society writ large. Features on it analyze data, trends, and perspectives from experts inside and outside of Darktrace to educate and inspire readers about the role that AI plays in enabling innovation and how it can be applied safely and securely.

I link to it since the first few pieces:

  • AI and the biggest election year ever – are we ready?
  • The role of IT support engineering in the age of AI
  • In conversation with Professor Mike Woolridge
  • Malware-as-a-Service: what you need to know about this persistent cyber threat

were very well crafted, and I thought more than a few readers would want to get this into their RSS feeds.

(As usual, I get nothing for Dropping a link to this post, save for providing y’all with something I found interesting.)

updated 2024-01-07T05:05:09

1 posts

1 repos

dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev at 2024-08-29T16:16:40.000Z ##

  • A guide on creating a custom Ollama model using a Modelfile to generate concise names for CVE vulnerabilities, similar to CISA’s KEV catalog entries (https://github.com/ollama/ollama/blob/main/docs/modelfile.md)
  • Discussion of Google’s new Pixel 9 “Reimagine” feature, which allows users to manipulate photos using AI, raising concerns about the potential misuse of such technology (https://www.theverge.com/2024/8/21/24224084/google-pixel-9-reimagine-ai-photos)
  • Introduction to “The Inference,” a new editorial project by Danny Palmer published by Darktrace, exploring the impact of AI on cybersecurity and society (https://darktrace.com/the-inference)

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by Pixabay on Pexels.com

  • FROM: Identifies the base model (mandatory)

  • SYSTEM: Sets up system messages

Your task is to convert verbose CVE descriptions into clear, descriptive titles that resemble entries in CISA's Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Stop generating output immediately after providing the short name.PROMPT Given a CVE description, create a short name similar to those used in CISA's KEV catalog. The short name should be concise, descriptive, and highlight the affected product or vulnerability type. Do not provide additional information or explanations. The response should be under 10 words and should end immediately after the short name.Examples:CVE description: A vulnerability in the TCP/IP stack of Cisco IOS XR Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.Short name: Cisco IOS XR TCP/IP Stack DoS VulnerabilityCVE description: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. Then just try it out:

$ ollama run cve-shortener 'Topline Opportunity Form (aka XLS Opp form) before 2015-02-15 does not properly restrict access to database-connection strings, which allows attackers to read the cleartext version of sensitive credential and e-mail address information via unspecified vectors.'Topline Opportunity Form (XLS Opp) Database Vulnerability

CVE-2021-31196
(7.2 HIGH)

EPSS: 6.17%

updated 2024-01-06T05:05:58

2 posts

Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2021-31206, CVE-2021-34473.

1 repos

https://github.com/hosch3n/ProxyVulns

cisakevtracker@mastodon.social at 2024-08-21T15:00:55.000Z ##

CVE ID: CVE-2021-31196
Vendor: Microsoft
Product: Exchange Server
Date Added: 2024-08-21
Vulnerability: Microsoft Exchange Server Information Disclosure Vulnerability
Notes: https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2021-31196
CVE URL: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-31196

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-21T14:40:38.000Z ##

CISA: CISA Adds Four Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
Super hot off the press!!! NOTE: I'm so quick that CISA hasn't even started the blog post yet, generating a Page Not Found page. I have it on good authority that the following are added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog:

  • CVE-2021-33044 (9.8 critical) Dahua IP Camera Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
  • CVE-2021-33045 (9.8 critical) Dahua IP Camera Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
  • CVE-2022-0185 (8.4 high) Linux Kernel Heap-Based Buffer Overflow
  • CVE-2021-31196 (7.2 high) Microsoft Exchange Server Information Disclosure Vulnerability

Edit: Until that link works above, or someone corrects me, heres's a link to CISA's KEV Catalog

#cisa #kev #vulnerability #CVE #knownexploitedvulnerabilitiescatalog #CVE_2021_33044 #CVE_2021_33045 #CVE_2022_0185 #CVE_2021_31196

##

CVE-2018-1000861
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.30%

updated 2023-12-22T14:07:25

1 posts

A code execution vulnerability exists in the Stapler web framework used by Jenkins 2.153 and earlier, LTS 2.138.3 and earlier in stapler/core/src/main/java/org/kohsuke/stapler/MetaClass.java that allows attackers to invoke some methods on Java objects by accessing crafted URLs that were not intended to be invoked this way.

Nuclei template

2 repos

https://github.com/smokeintheshell/CVE-2018-1000861

https://github.com/1NTheKut/CVE-2019-1003000_RCE-DETECTION

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-20T15:39:20.000Z ##

Just FYI, CISA quietly updated a column for CVE-2024-23897 in the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog:

Known To Be Used in Ransomware Campaigns? Known

See parent toots above for information on the Jenkins Command Line Interface (CLI) Path Traversal Vulnerability.

Why you should care about CVE-2024-23897:

  • CISA confirmed that CVE-2024-23897 is a Known Exploited Vulnerability today and added it to the KEV Catalog.
  • It's had a Proof of Concept since at least 4 days after the security advisory.
  • Jenkins is an attractive target for threat actors. Four other Jenkins vulnerabilities are in CISA's KEV Catalog: CVE-2015-5317, CVE-2019-1003029, CVE-2019-1003030 and CVE-2018-1000861.
  • It's already had exploitation attempts since 25 January 2024
  • Trend Micro also noted active exploitation on 19 March 2024. See Recent attacks section.
  • CloudSEK noted on 25 July 2024 that threat actor IntelBroker exploited CVE-2024-23897 to breach BORN Group's systems, exfiltrating sensitive data from multiple clients.
  • Ransomware groups have been known to exploit it: Juniper said on 13 August 2024 that RansomEXX leveraged CVE-2024-23897 to gain initial unauthorized access to Brontoo Technology Solutions.

#CVE_2024_23897 #vulnerability #cve #Jenkins #kev #eitw #activeexploitation #ransomware

##

CVE-2022-2601
(8.6 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.07%

updated 2023-12-04T05:04:58

5 posts

A buffer overflow was found in grub_font_construct_glyph(). A malicious crafted pf2 font can lead to an overflow when calculating the max_glyph_size value, allocating a smaller than needed buffer for the glyph, this further leads to a buffer overflow and a heap based out-of-bounds write. An attacker may use this vulnerability to circumvent the secure boot mechanism.

avoidthehack at 2024-08-26T18:22:31.376Z ##

@gary_alderson No. That's precisely the issue in this instance; any boot media using GRUBv2 (as far as I know) will get the SBAT violation, the machine will not boot into the media/OS attached to the machine without a fix for CVE-2022-2601… it just won’t boot with Secure Boot enabled (after installing the August 2024 Windows updates).

Virtualization is kind of irrelevant here - especially if you had a Linux install on a separate media but attached to the Windows machine. Sure, you could set up a virtualization environment after loading into Windows, but leaves people wanting to use Live OS or boot into a whole separate OS on that machine in the dust.

##
3kh0@defcon.social at 2024-08-24T02:23:26.000Z ##

tl;dr: Microsoft breaks dual-boot Windows and Linux PCs with security update sent to wrong systems. Links below:

A recent Microsoft security update (https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2022-2601), intended to fix a two-year-old vulnerability (https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-2601) in the GRUB boot loader, accidentally affected dual-boot systems running both Windows and Linux, when secure boot was enforced. This caused these systems to fail to boot, displaying an error message stating, "something has gone seriously wrong."

The issue arose because the update, which wasn't supposed to be sent to dual-boot systems, was mistakenly deployed to them. Several Linux distributions, such as Linux Mint, Puppy Linux, Ubuntu, and Zorin OS, are affected.

A workaround involves either disabling secure boot temporarily or deleting the problematic SBAT (https://askubuntu.com/a/1523416) data.

Reddit post: https://old.reddit.com/r/linux4noobs/comments/1euuiwv/
Ars Technica: https://arstechnica.com/security/2024/08/a-patch-microsoft-spent-2-years-preparing-is-making-a-mess-for-some-linux-users/

#news #tech #linux #microsoft #windows #linux

##
avoidthehack@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-26T18:22:31.000Z ##

@gary_alderson No. That's precisely the issue in this instance; any boot media using GRUBv2 (as far as I know) will get the SBAT violation, the machine will not boot into the media/OS attached to the machine without a fix for CVE-2022-2601… it just won’t boot with Secure Boot enabled (after installing the August 2024 Windows updates).

Virtualization is kind of irrelevant here - especially if you had a Linux install on a separate media but attached to the Windows machine. Sure, you could set up a virtualization environment after loading into Windows, but leaves people wanting to use Live OS or boot into a whole separate OS on that machine in the dust.

##
3kh0@defcon.social at 2024-08-24T02:23:26.000Z ##

tl;dr: Microsoft breaks dual-boot Windows and Linux PCs with security update sent to wrong systems. Links below:

A recent Microsoft security update (https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/en-US/advisory/CVE-2022-2601), intended to fix a two-year-old vulnerability (https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-2601) in the GRUB boot loader, accidentally affected dual-boot systems running both Windows and Linux, when secure boot was enforced. This caused these systems to fail to boot, displaying an error message stating, "something has gone seriously wrong."

The issue arose because the update, which wasn't supposed to be sent to dual-boot systems, was mistakenly deployed to them. Several Linux distributions, such as Linux Mint, Puppy Linux, Ubuntu, and Zorin OS, are affected.

A workaround involves either disabling secure boot temporarily or deleting the problematic SBAT (https://askubuntu.com/a/1523416) data.

Reddit post: https://old.reddit.com/r/linux4noobs/comments/1euuiwv/
Ars Technica: https://arstechnica.com/security/2024/08/a-patch-microsoft-spent-2-years-preparing-is-making-a-mess-for-some-linux-users/

#news #tech #linux #microsoft #windows #linux

##
dangoodin@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-21T01:08:09.000Z ##

Last Tuesday, loads of Linux users—many running packages released as early as this year—started reporting their devices were failing to boot. Instead, they received a cryptic error message that included the phrase: “Something has gone seriously wrong.”

The cause: an update Microsoft issued as part of its monthly patch release. It was intended to close a 2-year-old vulnerability in GRUB, an open source boot loader used to start up many Linux devices. The vulnerability, with a severity rating of 8.6 out of 10, made it possible for hackers to bypass secure boot. CVE-2022-2601 was discovered in 2022, but for unclear reasons, Microsoft patched it only last Tuesday.

https://arstechnica.com/security/2024/08/a-patch-microsoft-spent-2-years-preparing-is-making-a-mess-for-some-linux-users/

Note: Software versions which have reached End of Technical Support (EoTS) are not evaluated

Tenable: AA24-241A : Joint Cybersecurity Advisory on Iran-based Cyber Actors Targeting US Organizations
Tenable provides an impressive analysis of CISA's joint cybersecurity advisory about Iranian actors targeting U.S. organizations with ransomware (see parent toots above). They list out the CVEs leveraged, including CVE-2024-3400, CVE-2024-24919, CVE-2019-19781, CVE-2023-3519, CVE-2022-1388, and CVE-2024-21887. (I hate how I recognize every CVE ID based on how often I write about VPN and edge networking device vulnerabilities.) Tenable has graphics of Shodan searches for internet-facing instances, MITRE ATT&CK TTPs, and Tenable plugins.

EPSS: 79.22%

screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T18:16:44.206Z ##

Akamai: Beware the Unpatchable: Corona Mirai Botnet Spreads via Zero-Day
Reference: CVE-2024-7029 (CNA: 8.7 high, disclosed 02 August 2024 by CISA) AVTECH IP camera command injection vulnerability. See parent toot above for initial reporting from Security Week.

Akamai finally provides a writeup explaining the situation: a Corona Mirai variant Botnet is leveraging a previously undisclosed zero-day vulnerability now tracked as CVE-2024-7029 to add vulnerable AVTECH IP camera devices to its collection. IOC are provided. They describe the vulnerability (quoted text verbatim, bold emphasis is Akamai's):

The first active campaign we observed began on March 18, 2024, but analysis showed activity for this variant as early as December 2023. The proof of concept (PoC) for CVE-2024-7029 has been publicly available since at least 2019, but it never had a proper CVE assignment until August 2024.

The exploit of this vulnerability allows an attacker to execute remote code on a target system. Here are some bonus CVEs being exploited in the wild for your consideration (to the KEV Catalog):

The botnet also targeted several other vulnerabilities including a Hadoop YARN RCE, CVE-2014-8361, and CVE-2017-17215.

#threatintel #mirai #botnet #vulnerability #zeroday #cve #CVE_2024_7029 #avtech #cisa #rce #poc #corona #hadoop

CVE-2021-1879
(6.1 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.23%

updated 2023-02-02T05:01:16

6 posts

This issue was addressed by improved management of object lifetimes. This issue is fixed in iOS 12.5.2, iOS 14.4.2 and iPadOS 14.4.2, watchOS 7.3.3. Processing maliciously crafted web content may lead to universal cross site scripting. Apple is aware of a report that this issue may have been actively exploited..

screaminggoat at 2024-08-29T13:31:26.914Z ##

Google Threat Analysis Group (TAG) State-backed attackers and commercial surveillance vendors repeatedly use the same exploits
Google TAG observed multiple in-the-wild exploit campaigns, between November 2023 and July 2024, delivered from a watering hole attack on Mongolian government websites. They assess with moderate confidence the campaigns are linked to the Russian government-backed actor APT29. In each iteration of the watering hole campaigns, the attackers used exploits that were identical or strikingly similar to exploits previously used by commercial surveillance vendors (CSVs) Intellexa and NSO Group. Google TAG provides a timeline of the watering hole attack, Apple Safari campaign, Google Chrome campaign, and the Exploit reuse timeline. IOC provided.

APT29, aka Midnight Blizzard and Cozy Bear, is publicly attributed to Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the U.S. Government.

See related Bleeping Computer reporting: Russian APT29 hackers use iOS, Chrome exploits created by spyware vendors

#googletag #apt29 #Russia #cyberespionage #threatintel #infosec #IOC #intellexa #nsogroup #CVE_2023_41993 #CVE_2024_5274 #CVE_2024_4671 #CVE_2023_41993 #CVE_2021_1879 #CVE_2021_37973

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-29T13:31:26.000Z ##

LukaszOlejnik@mastodon.social at 2024-08-30T10:16:40.000Z ##

Russian cyber operators ('government hackers') were using tools that were identical or very similar to those previously created by spyware tool makers Intellex and NSO Group. It is not known how the Russians acquired these tools. The operations detected were aimed at spying on Mongolian government. Data was stolen, such as cookies from the Safari browser (CVE-2021-1879). https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/state-backed-attackers-and-commercial-surveillance-vendors-repeatedly-use-the-same-exploits/

It is not known how the Russians acquired these tools. The operations detected were aimed at spying on Mongolian government. Data was stolen, such as cookies from the Safari browser (CVE-2021-1879). https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/state-backed-attackers-and-commercial-surveillance-vendors-repeatedly-use-the-same-exploits/

##

CVE-2015-5317(CVSS UNKNOWN)

EPSS: 4.88%

updated 2023-02-01T05:08:11

1 posts

The Fingerprints pages in Jenkins before 1.638 and LTS before 1.625.2 might allow remote attackers to obtain sensitive job and build name information via a direct request.

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-20T15:39:20.000Z ##

Just FYI, CISA quietly updated a column for CVE-2024-23897 in the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog:

Known To Be Used in Ransomware Campaigns? Known

See parent toots above for information on the Jenkins Command Line Interface (CLI) Path Traversal Vulnerability.

Why you should care about CVE-2024-23897:

  • CISA confirmed that CVE-2024-23897 is a Known Exploited Vulnerability today and added it to the KEV Catalog.
  • It's had a Proof of Concept since at least 4 days after the security advisory.
  • Jenkins is an attractive target for threat actors. Four other Jenkins vulnerabilities are in CISA's KEV Catalog: CVE-2015-5317, CVE-2019-1003029, CVE-2019-1003030 and CVE-2018-1000861.
  • It's already had exploitation attempts since 25 January 2024
  • Trend Micro also noted active exploitation on 19 March 2024. See Recent attacks section.
  • CloudSEK noted on 25 July 2024 that threat actor IntelBroker exploited CVE-2024-23897 to breach BORN Group's systems, exfiltrating sensitive data from multiple clients.
  • Ransomware groups have been known to exploit it: Juniper said on 13 August 2024 that RansomEXX leveraged CVE-2024-23897 to gain initial unauthorized access to Brontoo Technology Solutions.

#CVE_2024_23897 #vulnerability #cve #Jenkins #kev #eitw #activeexploitation #ransomware

screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T16:33:44.894Z ##

Tenable: AA24-241A : Joint Cybersecurity Advisory on Iran-based Cyber Actors Targeting US Organizations
Tenable provides an impressive analysis of CISA's joint cybersecurity advisory about Iranian actors targeting U.S. organizations with ransomware (see parent toots above). They list out the CVEs leveraged, including CVE-2024-3400, CVE-2024-24919, CVE-2019-19781, CVE-2023-3519, CVE-2022-1388, and CVE-2024-21887. (I hate how I recognize every CVE ID based on how often I write about VPN and edge networking device vulnerabilities.) Tenable has graphics of Shodan searches for internet-facing instances, MITRE ATT&CK TTPs, and Tenable plugins.

#threatintel #iran #cyberespionage #CVE #vulnerability #ransomware

##

CVE-2024-72762
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.00%

4 posts

N/A

screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T14:57:44.725Z ##

ESET Research: Analysis of two arbitrary code execution vulnerabilities affecting WPS Office
No surprise that software vendor Kingsoft does not want to disclose in-the-wild zero-day exploitation of CVE-2024-7672 (9.3 critical, published 15 August 2024 and silently patched by Kingsoft sometime March 2024) WPS Office arbitrary code execution via path traversal (!!! cc: @cR0w @reverseics). It is being exploited by a South Korea-aligned Advanced Persistent Threat, called APT-C-60, to target East Asian countries. The final payload is a custom backdoor dubbed SpyGlace. ESET also discovered CVE-2024-7263 (9.3 critical, same info as previous 7262 CVE), which is an alternate method of hijacking the control flow of the same WPS Office plugin component. IOC provided.

See related The Hacker News reporting: APT-C-60 Group Exploit WPS Office Flaw to Deploy SpyGlace Backdoor

#threatintel #IOC #CVE_2024_72762 #CVE_2024_72763 #vulnerability #eitw #activeexploitation #cyberespionage #southkorea #APTC60 #IOC

CVE-2024-5274
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.35%

5 posts

N/A

2 repos

https://github.com/Alchemist3dot14/CVE-2024-5274-Detection

https://github.com/mistymntncop/CVE-2024-5274

screaminggoat at 2024-08-29T13:31:26.914Z ##

Google Threat Analysis Group (TAG) State-backed attackers and commercial surveillance vendors repeatedly use the same exploits
Google TAG observed multiple in-the-wild exploit campaigns, between November 2023 and July 2024, delivered from a watering hole attack on Mongolian government websites. They assess with moderate confidence the campaigns are linked to the Russian government-backed actor APT29. In each iteration of the watering hole campaigns, the attackers used exploits that were identical or strikingly similar to exploits previously used by commercial surveillance vendors (CSVs) Intellexa and NSO Group. Google TAG provides a timeline of the watering hole attack, Apple Safari campaign, Google Chrome campaign, and the Exploit reuse timeline. IOC provided.

APT29, aka Midnight Blizzard and Cozy Bear, is publicly attributed to Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the U.S. Government.

See related Bleeping Computer reporting: Russian APT29 hackers use iOS, Chrome exploits created by spyware vendors

#googletag #apt29 #Russia #cyberespionage #threatintel #infosec #IOC #intellexa #nsogroup #CVE_2023_41993 #CVE_2024_5274 #CVE_2024_4671 #CVE_2023_41993 #CVE_2021_1879 #CVE_2021_37973

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-29T13:31:26.000Z ##

Google Threat Analysis Group (TAG) State-backed attackers and commercial surveillance vendors repeatedly use the same exploits
Google TAG observed multiple in-the-wild exploit campaigns, between November 2023 and July 2024, delivered from a watering hole attack on Mongolian government websites. They assess with moderate confidence the campaigns are linked to the Russian government-backed actor APT29. In each iteration of the watering hole campaigns, the attackers used exploits that were identical or strikingly similar to exploits previously used by commercial surveillance vendors (CSVs) Intellexa and NSO Group. Google TAG provides a timeline of the watering hole attack, Apple Safari campaign, Google Chrome campaign, and the Exploit reuse timeline. IOC provided.

APT29, aka Midnight Blizzard and Cozy Bear, is publicly attributed to Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the U.S. Government.

See related Bleeping Computer reporting: Russian APT29 hackers use iOS, Chrome exploits created by spyware vendors

CVE-2024-22527
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.00%

2 posts

N/A

screaminggoat at 2024-08-30T13:05:57.210Z ##

Trend Micro: Silent Intrusions: Godzilla Fileless Backdoors Targeting Atlassian Confluence
Reference: CVE-2023-22527 (CNA: 10.0/NVD: 9.8 critical, disclosed 16 January 2024 by Atlassian, added to CISA's KEV Catalog 24 January 2024) Atlassian Confluence Data Center and Server Template Injection Vulnerability (RCE)

Not even two days later, Trend Micro reports more CVE-2024-22527 exploitation. This time, a loader leads to an in-memory fileless backdoor known as the Godzilla webshell. The original malware author claims that Godzilla avoids detection by using Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) encryption for its network traffic and boasts a very low static detection rate across various security vendor products. Trend Micro describes the infection chain and shares IOC.

#threatintel #godzilla #backdoor #CVE_2023_22527 #Atlassian #Confluence #vulnerability #CVE #eitw #activeexploitation #IOC #infosec #cybersecurity

CVE-2024-7672
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.00%

2 posts

N/A

screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T14:57:44.725Z ##

ESET Research: Analysis of two arbitrary code execution vulnerabilities affecting WPS Office
No surprise that software vendor Kingsoft does not want to disclose in-the-wild zero-day exploitation of CVE-2024-7672 (9.3 critical, published 15 August 2024 and silently patched by Kingsoft sometime March 2024) WPS Office arbitrary code execution via path traversal (!!! cc: @cR0w @reverseics). It is being exploited by a South Korea-aligned Advanced Persistent Threat, called APT-C-60, to target East Asian countries. The final payload is a custom backdoor dubbed SpyGlace. ESET also discovered CVE-2024-7263 (9.3 critical, same info as previous 7262 CVE), which is an alternate method of hijacking the control flow of the same WPS Office plugin component. IOC provided.

See related The Hacker News reporting: APT-C-60 Group Exploit WPS Office Flaw to Deploy SpyGlace Backdoor

#threatintel #IOC #CVE_2024_72762 #CVE_2024_72763 #vulnerability #eitw #activeexploitation #cyberespionage #southkorea #APTC60 #IOC

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-28T14:57:44.000Z ##

ESET Research: Analysis of two arbitrary code execution vulnerabilities affecting WPS Office
No surprise that software vendor Kingsoft does not want to disclose in-the-wild zero-day exploitation of CVE-2024-7672 (9.3 critical, published 15 August 2024 and silently patched by Kingsoft sometime March 2024) WPS Office arbitrary code execution via path traversal (!!! cc: @cR0w @reverseics). It is being exploited by a South Korea-aligned Advanced Persistent Threat, called APT-C-60, to target East Asian countries. The final payload is a custom backdoor dubbed SpyGlace. ESET also discovered CVE-2024-7263 (9.3 critical, same info as previous 7262 CVE), which is an alternate method of hijacking the control flow of the same WPS Office plugin component. IOC provided.

See related The Hacker News reporting: APT-C-60 Group Exploit WPS Office Flaw to Deploy SpyGlace Backdoor

#threatintel #IOC #CVE_2024_72762 #CVE_2024_72763 #vulnerability #eitw #activeexploitation #cyberespionage #southkorea #APTC60 #IOC

https://hydra.nixos.org/api/push?jobsets=nixpkgs:trunk,nixos:trunk-combined

How many security bad practices can you combine in one single HTTP endpoint?

CVE-2024-22263
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.04%

2 posts

N/A

1 repos

https://github.com/securelayer7/CVE-2024-22263_Scanner

screaminggoat at 2024-08-22T14:17:47.037Z ##

SecureLayer7: CVE-2024-22263: Spring Cloud Dataflow Arbitrary File Writing
"Spring Cloud Dataflow is a comprehensive toolkit designed for building and orchestrating data pipelines in a microservices architecture." SecureLayer7 provided a technical analysis of CVE-2024-22263 (8.8 high, disclosed 19 June 2024) Spring Cloud Data Flow arbitrary file write, from patch diffing to static and dynamic analysis (with proof of concept). The vulnerability exists in PackageService.java.

Here lies the issue: the upload was supposed to occur under /tmp/skipperUpload1128613998285237062, but due to the unfiltered name we provided, a directory traversal occurs, resulting in the path "/tmp/skipperUpload1128613998285237062/../../poc.

#poc #cve_2024_22263 #spring #vulnerability #CVE #proofofconcept

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-22T14:17:47.000Z ##

SecureLayer7: CVE-2024-22263: Spring Cloud Dataflow Arbitrary File Writing
"Spring Cloud Dataflow is a comprehensive toolkit designed for building and orchestrating data pipelines in a microservices architecture." SecureLayer7 provided a technical analysis of CVE-2024-22263 (8.8 high, disclosed 19 June 2024) Spring Cloud Data Flow arbitrary file write, from patch diffing to static and dynamic analysis (with proof of concept). The vulnerability exists in PackageService.java.

Here lies the issue: the upload was supposed to occur under /tmp/skipperUpload1128613998285237062, but due to the unfiltered name we provided, a directory traversal occurs, resulting in the path "/tmp/skipperUpload1128613998285237062/../../poc.

#poc #cve_2024_22263 #spring #vulnerability #CVE #proofofconcept

CVE-2024-32664
(0 None)

EPSS: 0.04%

2 posts

N/A

screaminggoat at 2024-08-22T14:14:02.255Z ##

Kaspersky: Memory corruption vulnerabilities in Suricata and FreeRDP
Kaspersky reported several vulnerabilities in Suricata and FreeRDP. Suricata is an open source network analysis and threat detection software, while FreeRDP is a free implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP), released under the Apache license. This blog post describes some of those vulnerabilities: CVE-2024-32664 is an out-of-bounds write in Suricata, while the six vulnerabilities in FreeRDP are a combination of out-of-bounds read/write and integer underflow/overflow types found using a FreeRDP-specific fuzzer. All of these reported vulnerabilities were patched.

#vulnerability #Suricata #FreeRDP #cve

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-22T14:14:02.000Z ##

Kaspersky: Memory corruption vulnerabilities in Suricata and FreeRDP
Kaspersky reported several vulnerabilities in Suricata and FreeRDP. Suricata is an open source network analysis and threat detection software, while FreeRDP is a free implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP), released under the Apache license. This blog post describes some of those vulnerabilities: CVE-2024-32664 is an out-of-bounds write in Suricata, while the six vulnerabilities in FreeRDP are a combination of out-of-bounds read/write and integer underflow/overflow types found using a FreeRDP-specific fuzzer. All of these reported vulnerabilities were patched.

#vulnerability #Suricata #FreeRDP #cve

Product: Kernel

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-21T14:40:38.000Z ##

CISA: CISA Adds Four Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
Super hot off the press!!! NOTE: I'm so quick that CISA hasn't even started the blog post yet, generating a Page Not Found page. I have it on good authority that the following are added to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog:

  • CVE-2021-33044 (9.8 critical) Dahua IP Camera Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
  • CVE-2021-33045 (9.8 critical) Dahua IP Camera Authentication Bypass Vulnerability
  • CVE-2022-0185 (8.4 high) Linux Kernel Heap-Based Buffer Overflow
  • CVE-2021-31196 (7.2 high) Microsoft Exchange Server Information Disclosure Vulnerability

Edit: Until that link works above, or someone corrects me, heres's a link to CISA's KEV Catalog
